Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2012 09:25PM - edited Jun 8, 2012 04:59PM by dobie I created a separate thread with this question before I found this thread, but this looks like the right place for this. I talked to my MO last week and asked him about getting a Oncotype Dx. I did not feel strongly about getting it because the 2 ILC tumors found in my breast were 0.2 cm each so I really don't think that qualifies for chemo no matter what the Oncotype # is. And i just had UmX on previously radiated breast, so won't be getting rads. Agreed to Aromatase inhibitor. But I told him I could not ignore the option of a PMX to manage risk in my left breast especially since this is not easily seen on mamo or MRI. My thinking is that a low Oncotype will be reassuring and a higher one will steer me toward surgery. I know this is not really what this test is designed for. But MO was sympathetic to my dilemma and ordered the test and insurance covers 100% so husband says, why not? Im kinda surprised he went with it , i wasnt realy pushing for it, just wanted to address the issue. Now i am wondering what i am going to do with this information when i get it especially if its high. Anyone have ideas, knowledge, opinion, data on this ? I am ER 100% + PR neg, her2 neg. don't see a ki67 on my report but mitotic score is 1 (low). So I really don't expect a high score but from what I'm reading here, you never know for sure.
Posts.Title: Another Oncotype question mary71 Scarlet2

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2012 05:22PM dobie wrote: Purple 32- when I was dx 5 years ago the programs indicated that although taking medication would reduce my risk of reocurrance. It did not change my survival. That is because, when you have a small relatively nonaggresive tumor which has not gone to lymph nodes your survival rate is very good no matter what you do. And if it does reoccur it will probably be small and non aggressive again. Probably. Like Dianarose said, no one has a crystal ball. I chose not to take medication and just had a reocurrance. Again early detection is my saving grace and this cancer still will not effect my survival rate much, but it cost me my breast this time. I decided to take a aromatase inhibitor this time. Cancer is just no fun, and I don't want to press my luck any further. That's me. Everyone has to decide for themselves taking into consideration their tolerance for risk of disease vs risks associated with medications. No easy choices.
Posts.Title: Another Oncotype question mary71 Scarlet2

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2012 04:57PM - edited Jun 8, 2012 04:58PM by dobie Sorry for the confusion. That information is all from my pathology report post surgery. I do not have my Oncotype testing results back yet. Don't expect it for a week or so..
Posts.Title: Another Oncotype question mary71 Scarlet2

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2012 03:44PM - edited Jun 16, 2012 04:06PM by dobie Comments on the last few hours of discussion: Purple 32- It made sense to me not to take hormonal therapy 5 years ago, based on what I knew and it makes sense to me now to take it now that the situation is different. I wish you had better options for yourself. I wish we all had better options. That's what I mean, no easy decisions. Lisa2012- this is my understanding of survival vs reocurrance: Not everyone who gets BC dies of BC. Those of us who have early, small cancers detected then treated are not very likely to die of the disease even if it reoccurs. Our survival rate is darned near 100%. So taking tamoxifen or an aromatase inhibitor (AI). Will reduce the risk of reocurrance but it will not change risk of dying of BC because our risk is already very very small. This is the reason that some people will chose not to take the risk of hormonal therapies. Some chose to live with the risk of reocurrance rather than the risks of side effects and change in quality of life from tami and AIs. But there are so many other factors that go into individual decisions, that is why it is so personal. I have been very impressed (for the most part) with the respect posters have for each others decisions. Julz4- I have been a women's health care provider and certified menopause practitioner for many years and have read a lot of studies about hormones and birth control. There is no evidence that hormones cause breast cancer. The combination of estrogen and progestin together may slightly increase risk of BC but does not cause it. In fact the 2002 WHI study that got so much press actually showed that taking estrogen only, decreased risk. Your friend with the hysterectomy, almost certainly got just estrogen since progestins are given with estrogen to protect against uterine cancer which is a SE of unapposed estrogen. Truth is no one knows for sure what causes BC other than the BRCA gene. Yeah, that pretty much causes it, but other than that...We all know people who seemingly have no risk factors and get it and those who took hormones, drink , don't exercise, eat unhealthily who never will get it. Go figure. Irregardless, no one deserves it. Let's hope in our lifetimes we see this puzzle solved. Ok. That's my 2 cents worth. Edited to add: Purple 32- You do know that Tamoxifen actually acts like estrogen on bone and can increase bone mass, don't you?
Posts.Title: Another Oncotype question mary71 Scarlet2

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2012 06:45AM dobie wrote: Like I tomed earlier, I discussed the Oncotype testing with MO and to my surprise he ordered it without a fuss despite the fact that I do not fit the guidelines having two 0.2 mm tumors. Guidelines are just that and not law. Each physician or system can make their own judgements and decisions about testing. Obviously, Mass general has a policy not to order testing in cases like Purple's. But policies can be changed, so I also encourage you to push for it. I got a call from genomics a few days after MO ordered test stating that insurance would cover test and did I want to go ahead with it? The MO ordered it on condition of my final approval, giving me the choice to have it or not after knowing insurance status. I am one of those cases, as voracious stated above, where my score will help me make other treatment decisions besides chemo. Good luck, Purple.
Posts.Title: Another Oncotype question mary71 Scarlet2

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2012 10:02AM dobie wrote: I think it all comes down to personal values,philosophy and personality. I value the sensitivity of my breasts. My philosophy is that I want to keep as much of my body intact as long as possible. My personality is that I am not a huge worry-wart. I had lumpectomy and radiation 5 years ago for dx of DCIS then they found a small ILC. Despite my current dilema i still beleive it was the right decision for me then. I also chose not to take tamoxifen due to concern about side effects. Iam now in process of deciding everything again after dx of pleomorphic LCIS in same breast. Some docs think it acts like DCIS and breast should come off. Others say there is not enough evidence and an excisional biopsy is enough until proof of invasive disease. Lit says this particular beast effects both breasts and is multifocal therefore a logical option is BMX. Geesh! The docs don't know what is best for you. They have all told me that my chances of survival, which is very good BTW wont change no matter what i decide There is no right or wrong. We each have to make our own choice doing the best we can with the limited info we have. I have'nt decided yet but when I do I won't second guess. Just move on.

Posts.Content: dobie wrote: THe path report from the lumpectomy 7/26 shows invasive lobular cancer along with the DCIS. I did not have SNB with lump so I know that will need to be done at least. I did not see the report yet since the surgeon got a verbal report after paging the pathologist since it wasnt posted at my appointment on Friday. It was taking longer 'cause the pathologist was having a 2nd pathologist look at my slides. So I don't have all the details. It was very small. I think he said 2mm with 4 mm clear margin, except for a few cells of LCIS around the edge. After doing some looking I have learned that ILC is relatively rare-10-15% of BC compared with 80% IDC. I have also read that it is more often multifocal and contralateral. It is not easily dx since it often does not show up on mammogram or US. It seems that it was a pure accident that they found this ILC since it was the DCIS that showed up on the mammogram. How can I know there is not more unseen ILC lurking in either breast? I know I need to wait for the rest of the picture ( I will get a copy of my report on Monday) and my case is going to the tumor board next week so I will wait to see what they say but this seems to be a horse of a whole different color. I would really like to keep my breasts but... any thoughts, info, experiences that may be helpful? Thanks- Dobie Dobie-March 2012 LCIS rt breast Pleomorphic. Dx 7/2007, ILC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 6/1/2012 Arimidex (anastrozole) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 20, 2012 10:11AM dobie wrote: Thought I'd check in 3 days post-op, s/p rt MX with reconstruction with immediate implant. Don't really need pain med now, just feels a little tight. Sleeping well on a wedge in my bed, with pillows under knees. I have been a stomach sleeper all my life so that was a concern but no problem. I'm sure the drugs help. I have good range of movement in arm and can easily raise above head to dress. Walked through the neighborhood yesterday and today a few miles. Took a shower today and dried foam tape dressing with hair dryer. DH taped fresh 4x4 dressing on drain site. I agree that the drains are the biggest annoyance. Will see PS on 5/22 and was told will probably get one drain out. Goal today is BM. Took MOM and have been taking Colace since 1st day. So let's get on with it already. Other than that I feel pretty darn good! Take care all. Sorry Vickie, don't have advice for you about PET/CT scan.

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2012 02:35PM - edited Jun 13, 2012 02:38PM by dobie Cailindearg- Dontcha love how we all like to share our experiences? Somehow it helps to know someone else will get some benefit from it. I will be 4 weeks out tomorow from NSMx and SNB on right side only with immediate implant. Drain out Monday so 25 days ( but who was counting!) with drain. I rode my bike 8 miles/ 40 min yesterday and did fine. My main concern about camping would be sleeping. I still am not comfortable lying flat or on my side. I use a bed wedge with pillows on it to keep me partially sitting up and it works fine for me. I am small breasted as well and have not worn a bra hardly at all. I came home from hospital with breast wrapped and supported in foam tape like a bra which I slowly peeled off after about a week My drain site was right where the edge of a bra would lie so it has not been comfortable to wear one and PS said no problem. I have taped my nips flat as needed or wore tops which did not show . I do have a couple Genie bras and have worn them a few times. I like them. If you decide on getting then I recommend getting a bigger size than what they say on box so they are not too tight. According to my measurements I would take a med but got a XXL and it works just fine. Best of luck to you.

Posts.Content: May 25, 2012 04:03PM dobie wrote: Although I don't have much experience with SNB scars, I look at a lot of C/S scars post op and I agree that it does not sound serious. I had surgery on 5 /17 and my incision site looks alot like you are describing. You might want to just place a 4x4 gauze over it for a little protection when you wear something that might rub against it. Problems to report would be if it starts oozing yellow with an odor, more swollen or becomes painful. But don't worry if an infection does start, it can easily be controlled with antibiotic. I tell my patients to gently wash area with an antibacterial soap and keep dry. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: May 18, 2012 08:04AM - edited May 18, 2012 11:30AM by dobie Rt NSMX went without a hitch yesterday. Just waiting to be discharged from hospital today. Bruised, swollen but still look amazingly like me. Direct implant with acellular dermis ( like alloderm). Took 3 nodes. Incision acoss my infra mammary fold (under breast). 2 drains. Vicodin and a muscle relaxer (soma) doing the trick for pain. I did take some IV Dilaudid last night and managed to get about 4-5 hrs sleep. I'm sure I will sleep better when I get home. I have just a water proof wide foam tape under and over my new breast for support. Told I could shower. No bra or cami. PS said she would talk to me about surgical bra when I saw her next Tues. About a week for pathology results. So thats my story. Take care everyone.
Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

Posts.Content: May 22, 2012 01:41PM - edited May 23, 2012 05:48AM by dobie Just got back from the PS s/p rt NSMX on 5/17. Surprised they already had the path report. And as feared they did find invasive lobular cancer (ILC), 2 very small areas 0.2 cm each. The area of LCIS was >4 cm. 4 nodes negative. The most disappointing finding was LCIS in nipple tissue which means the nip will probably have to go. I am so not surprised about the ILC. That is exactly what happened to me 5 years ago. And now I am seriously rethinking the PMX for my left breast. How can they know what is lurking there? So some good news ( neg nodes, small IBC) and some not so great news ( nipple goes?) They will present my case at tumor board on thurs and make recommendations. Oh BTW, got one drain removed, go back next week.

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2012 12:15PM - edited Jun 3, 2012 12:16PM by dobie Just catching up on all the posts over the last few days. Here are my comments: Yes, I have that tight feeling across chest. Usually happens in the evening when I am tired. My impression is that it is a pectoral muscle spasm since implant is stuffed under it stretching it out and it's not happy about it. My PS gave me a muscle relaxer called Soma which seems to help a lot more than a pain pill . And yes, I am numb too. It really bothers me the most. Feels like this part of my body does not belong to me. I bought the Genie bra before surgery and like it as well. According to box I would take a med. but I got a XXL for comfort. Has anyone heard of the group who makes "knitted knockers" for those who have not gotten reconstruction. Was that here? Can't remember which forum I heard about this on. Anyway, these would be great to stuff into the genie bra pockets if you need it. If you goggle this should be able to find it. I have been sleeping on a bed wedge covered with pillows since surgery. I am a terrible flip flopper in my sleep and like to sleep on my stomach. I was afraid I would pull the drains out. With the wedge and a pillow under my knees it has kept me on my back and fairly comfortable. Keep healing everyone. Keep your fingers crossed that my drain gives it up so I can get it removed tomorrow. Since it has been hovering at 30 cc for days I have my doubts, but one can hope. Yes, I have acellular dermis matrix ( alloderm generic) .
Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

I don't have TEs but if you have read the posts You know that plenty do have them and you will get lots of understanding an tips for managing. I surely have had my little pity party moments while still remembering how blessed I truly am. I feel entitled to those moments. BC sucks. You are entitled to those moments as well. It has helped me and I hope it will help you too. Welcome.

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2012 04:25PM - edited Jun 1, 2012 04:29PM by dobie Tmramirez- You are already a survivor! Best wishes to you for an easy journey down the chemo road. In summary of my experience from 5/17 UMX. I still have one drain and hope to have it removed Monday. Developed bladder infection and back on antibiotics. Geeze. Saw MO yesterday and am starting on Arimidix. Will get dexa bone scan baseline done. Don't need chemo. Plan MRI in September, mostly for close monitoring of left breast. Asked for and am getting Oncotype Dx done. Even though it won't change treatment plan or determine need for chemo, it may influence my decision to either get or not get a PMX for left breast. Plan nipple nipping in december. Congratulations to all of us in the May mastectomy class of 2012. We made it. Thank you from the bottom of my heart for all the heart felt wishes and thoughts, wisdom and wisecracks, tears and fears. It has made the journey easier and more interesting. I am uplifted just knowing there are people like you in the world. Really. I wish you all health, symmetry and contracture free happiness.

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2012 04:55PM dobie wrote: Not quite sure where to ask this question and may need to start a new thread for this so let me know what you think. I talked to my MO last week and asked him about getting a Oncotype Dx. I did not feel strongly about it cause the 2 ILC tumors in my breast were 0.2 cm each so I really don't think that qualifies for chemo no matter what the Oncotype # is. But I told him I could not ignore the option of a PMX to manage risk in my left breast especially since this is not easily seen on mamo or MRI. My thinking is that a low Oncotype will be reassuring and a higher one will steer me toward surgery. I know this is not really what this test is designed for. But MO was sympathetic to my dilemma and ordered the test and insurance covers 100% so husband says, why not? Now i am wondering what i am going to do with this information when i get it Anyone have info, knowledge, opinion, data on this ?

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 08:18PM - edited Apr 12, 2012 08:21PM by dobie Sorry about your dx. I was dx with ILC ( invasive lobular cancer ) in 2007. Also found by biopsy of calcifications. The calcium deposits are a byproduct of increased cell growth. Tx depends on the size of the tumor and that may not be determined until surgery. If it looks contained in one area of the breast they may give you the option of a lumpectomy. That is what I had. Outpatient, easy-peasy. If it looks larger they may recommend a mastectomy. When you have surgery they will test your lymph nodes to make sure it hasn't spread. Mine had not spread outside the breast so I had 7 weeks of radiation to that breast with very few side effects. All in all the worse part of my experience was the numbing fear. I always tell people that if I knew then what I know now I would have saved myself a ton of worry. So my advise to you is to try and not get too far ahead of yourself. About 90% of everything we worry about never happens. I wish you a easy and safe journey thru this scary experience.
Posts.Title: Pleomorphic Calcifications - Biopsy Monday Butterflylady2012 Moderators

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2012 08:50PM - edited Apr 11, 2012 09:03PM by dobie Firstly, I think jgisme, who started this thread, said her surgery was scheduled for today so my prayers are with her. Secondly, it has been very interesting to me how sure others ( without BC) are about what they would do if faced with this decision. "oh I would have them both off". Or " why on earth would anyone have a healthy breast removed?". As those of us who are faced with this dilemma knows, it is not an easy decision. I had hx of ILC 5 yrs ago with lump and rads. Now suspicious mammo and biopsy with pathology of pleomorphic LCIS in same breast. Despite that they gave me the option of just a local excision. BS said there is no evidence of invasive ca at this time, no reason for mx at this time. Except if IBC is found and mx is definitely needed cosmetic option of nip/ skin sparing mx is gone. So my decision is a UMX. Not ready to give up both despite increased risk in other breast. If tests, tami, worry gets too much I will reconsider. But now this feels right for me. I will not regret my decision, I will not look back. Just move forward. Good luck to all in coming to peace in your own heads with your own decision. Amen.
Posts.Title: Unilateral vs. Bilateral MX: regrets? jgisme GreenEyes57

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2007 02:44PM dobie wrote: Dessy- Years ago I was a research assistant for a study that looked at nipple fluid that we expressed from study participants with a device that looked like a little breast pump. One thing we looked at was betacarotenes in the fluid and if there was a difference between women who had breast fed or not. Anyway.. the point I want to make is that everyone will get some nipple discharge to some extent with enough stimulation. We had clear, yellow, green maybe it depends on diet too. In general unless the fluid is spontaneous or bloody I don't think it is too worrisome. I do women's health care (nurse midwife) and I have done slides for patients like a PAP smear on breast fluids and send to pathology just to be sure. It may be worth it for peace of mind. Good luck.

Posts.Content: May 5, 2012 04:49PM dobie wrote: StacyMarie-  Are you still looking? I can't beleive a big place like Chicago does not have plenty of forward thinking surgeons.   I am having a NS/SS MX on 5/17 for LCIS.  My PS is Donna Tepper at Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit.  She was the one who mentioned it and she was very enthusiastic that I was a good candidate for it. She says not everyone is. But since LCIS is not invasive, as long as it is not close to nipple or skin it can be done safely.  Even my pretty conservative BS has agreed to it  now and 5 years ago he said no way.   I had a lumpectomy at that time.
